awd_titl_txt: NRT-UtB: University of South Dakota Neuroscience and Nanotechnology Network
awd_abstract_narration:
The environment facing today's graduate students in STEM fields is changing rapidly. The number of STEM PhD students obtaining tenure-track jobs in academia is decreasing, and consequently, STEM graduate degree holders are increasingly finding jobs in non-academic fields. This means that the model for training STEM graduate students needs to change to accommodate the potential career paths that current and future generations of these students may enter. These include training in topics such as science policy, project management, finance, entrepreneurship, understanding intellectual property rights and technology transfer, and how to work in interdisciplinary teams. This National Science Foundation Research Traineeship (NRT) award to the University of South Dakota will develop a training plan that incorporates a truly interdisciplinary vision of research with the development of professional skills to enhance students' preparation for and success in careers inside and outside of academia. The project anticipates training forty (40) MS and PhD graduate students, including twenty (20) funded trainees, from the departments of Chemistry and Basic Biomedical Sciences.

Students will receive interdisciplinary research training that will focus on the development and application of nanotechnology-based tools to better understand brain function and develop treatments for brain disorders. Graduate students engaged in these projects will receive both classroom and laboratory training in nanotechnology-based chemistry and neuroscience research skills. What is novel about the STEM training in this program is that the student trainees will themselves be developing interdisciplinary expertise as part of their training, as opposed to the traditional, discipline-specific approach. The research will be complemented by the development of professional skills that include training to improve communication to both scientific and general audiences, sessions with scientists representing non-academic careers, and a series of classes (microtracks) from the University of South Dakota Beacom School of Business. These microtrack courses will be in themes such as finance, product development, entrepreneurship, and intellectual property rights. Finally, students will have the opportunity to participate in internships with both regional and national companies that utilize STEM expertise. This training program will develop a cadre of STEM graduate students with both the research and professional skills to better address current and future STEM workforce requirements. 

The NSF Research Traineeship (NRT) Program is designed to encourage the development and implementation of bold, new potentially transformative models for STEM graduate education training. The Traineeship Track is dedicated to effective training of STEM graduate students in high priority interdisciplinary research areas, through the comprehensive traineeship model that is innovative, evidence-based, and aligned with changing workforce and research needs.

por.por_cntn:
The major goals of the University of South Dakota Neuroscience, Nanotechnology and Networks (USD-N3) program are to provide a multidisciplinary model of graduate STEM education that better prepares students for a diverse range of careers in the government, academia, and the private sector. Trainees targeted by the program were PhD and MS in the following departments, Basic Biomedical Sciences, Biology, Chemistry, and Biomedical Engineering. Trainee research projects were required to include neuroscience plus either materials sciences or bioinformatics. All trainees had a primary and secondary mentor representing one of these three disciplines.

In addition to multidisciplinary research, the following training elements were used to enhance professional development and prepare students for multiple potential career paths. All students complete a myIDP (individual development plan) with their primary mentor on an annual basis. This plan shared USD-N3 administration to confirm that the program was meeting the students? needs, especially in the stated goal of the myIDP changed over the course of the training period (as they often did). The program also provided a workshop every year, for both faculty and students, on how to use the myIDP tool. Trainees were also required to attend professional development workshops organized by the program (about 2 per semester). These workshops provided exposure to STEM professionals in non-academic careers (e.g., biotech, science writing, or government positions) as well as skill-training (e.g., interviewing, presentation skills, entrepreneurship bootcamp). Stipend-supported trainees were also required to take 2-3 ?microcredential? classes. These classes were graduate level, non-STEM classes provided by the Business School, Law School, School of Education, and Communication Department and included topics in Health Management, Entrepreneurship, Accounting, Intellectual Property Regulation, Adult Education, and Mass Communication. There were also opportunities to participate in internships with the support USD-N3 program.

Project outcomes in terms of intellectual merits are as follows.

Twenty-two stipend-supported students and 16 non-stipend supported students. Examples of trainees projects include the development of a targeted drug delivery system for neurovascular diseases and mental health disorders, studies of pain and how it alters behavior, development of experimental and bioinformatic approaches to assess community-level usage of drugs of abuse using waste-water sampling approaches, using integrative multi-omics analysis of medulloblastoma sub-types and their corresponding level of metastasis to reveal potential brain tumor molecular signatures, and Study of immune responses of human cell lines and brain tissue following transfection of influenza virus proteins or influenza virus infection.

To date, trainees have generated 33 published articles and 117 professional presentations at the local, regional, and national level. Several participated in writing or contributing to writing successful grants including NSF Graduate Research Fellowship, NSF XCEDE award, NIH NIAAA Research Internship, participation on an NSF I-CORP project, and contributed to writing a NSF Instructional Capacity Excellence in Tribal Colleges (ICE-TI) grant. Internships that trainees participated in included internships supported by NRT funding. Internship sites included the Brookhaven National Laboratory, Amicus Therapeutics, Tailored Medical Devices, Merck Pharmaceutical (Writing Intern), the Dakota Research and Consulting Organization (DRACO), the USD Technology Transfer Office, NIH NIAAA research internship, South Dakota EPSCoR, and Little Priest Tribal College.

Of the 14 stipend-supported trainees that have graduated/left USD, two trainees are working as researchers at academic institutions, one is working as a researcher at a private basic biomedical science research institution, one is faculty at a primarily undergraduate institution, two are currently in medical school, one is working in hospital/health provider institution, two are working in private biotechnology companies, and two are working as research chemists in the private sector.  

 

 Project outcomes in terms of broader impacts are as follows.

Professional development is now recognized as a critical goal for STEM graduate training. The professional development workshops developed by the USD-N3 have continued even though the funding has ended, and other institutional elements have begun to host similar workshops as well. The myIDP has now become a requirement for most of the STEM graduate programs at USD. A 3 Minute Thesis (3MT) competition was developed by the program and has now been taken over by the USD Office of Graduate Studies.

In terms of improving the diversity within STEM graduate programs, of the twenty-two stipend-supported trainees recruited, thirteen (59%) trainees were women, eleven (50%) were first-generation college students, and two (10%) self-identified as a racial minority (Native American and African American). The co-PI of the program also started a 10-week ?Entering Mentoring? workshop that is now in its sixth year.

USD faculty were also able to leverage the training plan and lessons-learned from this NRT project into a successful application for a T32 Graduate Research Training Initiative for Student Enhancement (G-RISE) grant from the NIH/National Institute for General Medicine (NIGMS). The goal of this program is to enhance the diversity of the biomedical research field.
